channel.title: Data Viz - Digg
channel.description: Data Viz on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: The Job Losses Caused By The Coronavirus Pandemic Compared To Other Historical Periods Of Job Loss, Visualized
item.description: Over the last four weeks, more than 22 million people have filed jobless claims filed because of COVID-19. Here's how that compares to the numbers of other historical job losses over the past few decades.

item.title: How Our Top Google Searches Have Changed During The Coronavirus
item.description: April 2019 was a simpler time. Americans wanted to know what a black hole was, who was playing in the Final Four and how many episodes of "Game of Thrones" there were.

item.title: Coronavirus Testing Needs To Triple Before The United States Can Reopen, Experts Say
item.description: As some governors consider easing social distancing restrictions, new estimates by researchers at Harvard University suggest that the United States cannot safely reopen unless it conducts more than three times the number of coronavirus tests it is currently administering over the next month.
item.kicker: A MINIMUM OF 152 TESTS PER 100K PEOPLE

item.title: The Occupations With The Highest Risk Of Coronavirus Exposure, Visualized
item.description: According to this chart from Visual Capitalist, some US workers are more susceptible to putting themselves in harm's way.

item.title: Interactive: How The Coronavirus Is Changing How Americans View One Another
item.description: A new survey shows an increase in feelings of solidarity.

item.title: Where The World's Ultra-Rich Live, Broken Down By Country
item.description: Here are the nations where the people who are worth more than $30 million are residing.

item.title: The Huge Cost Of Waiting To Contain The Pandemic
item.description: As the numbers show, the timing of social distancing can have an enormous impact on death tolls.

item.title: The 'Office' Cast Members Who Had The Most Screen Time In Each Season, Charted
item.description: Here are the actors who had the most screen time in sitcom, ranked.

item.title: An Animated Chart Of The Biggest Fast Food Franchises In The World In The Past 50 Years
item.description: In the world of fast food chains, which franchise reigns supreme when it comes to the number of stores worldwide?

item.title: How Much Coronavirus Lockdowns Have Reduced Pollution In Major Cities, Visualized
item.description: The concentration of nitrogen dioxide has dropped substantially in cities around the world since the implementation of lockdown measures to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Why Hasn't The United States Adequately Mapped The Spread Of The Coronavirus?
item.description: Why isn't the United States doing extensive contact tracing for the coronavirus like in South Korea? Johnny Harris gives the history of tracking the spread of diseases and why the United States failed to effectively do this for the current pandemic.

item.title: How Urban Or Rural Is Your State? And What Does That Mean For The 2020 Election?
item.description: The 2016 election may not have been a realignment by historical standards, but it did bring the country's political divides more in line with its cultural divides — the biggest of which may be the growing chasm between urban and rural Americans.

item.title: A Visualization Of Major Diseases Throughout History And Your Odds Of Dying From It
item.description: A comparison of the worst outbreaks over the years and the likelihood of dying from it.

item.title: Challenging Joe Rogan On The Infinite Monkey Theorem Experiment
item.description: What happens when you combine music, Joe Rogan, and probability?

item.title: How The Virus Transformed The Way Americans Spend Their Money
item.description: The coronavirus has profoundly altered daily life in America, ushering in sweeping upheavals to the U.S. economy. Among the most immediate effects of the crisis? Radical changes to how people spend their money.

item.title: The Products That Have Seen The Biggest Online Shopping Increases Since The Pandemic Started, Charted
item.description: The COVID pandemic has led to some drastic changes in online shopping behavior. Here are the goods that people have buying more these days.

item.title: Visualizing Whether Or Not Your Hospital Is At Risk Of Being Overwhelmed By COVID-19 Patients
item.description: Amid the covid-19 pandemic, pinpointing the number and location of ICU beds, ventilators and doctors with specialized training is critical for local, state and federal officials trying to forge an effective response.

item.title: A New Way To Measure How Far Countries Are From Stopping The Coronavirus
item.description: To get a sense of how far each country is from containing the disease, we can look at a new shape that charts the rate at which people are dying from the disease.

item.title: A Probability Comparison Of The Rarest Things In The Universe
item.description: An interesting visualization comparing different rare occurrences.

item.title: Another Way To See The Recession: Power Usage Is Way Down
item.description: When the economy is moving too fast for the usual indicators, the electricity grid offers a valuable clue.

item.title: How Much World Governments Are Spending On Coronavirus Economic Relief, Visualized
item.description: Mapping out how much other nations were spending on their economic relief plans.
item.kicker: GOTTA SPEND MONEY TO SAVE ECONOMY

item.title: Coronavirus Was Slow To Spread To Rural America. Not Anymore
item.description: A late-arriving wave of illness could overwhelm rural communities that are older, poorer and sicker than much of the country.

item.title: History's Deadliest Pandemics, From Ancient Rome To Modern America
item.description: History shows that past pandemics have reshaped societies in profound ways.

item.title: The Price Changes Of Goods Compared To Wages In The US Over The Past 30 Years, Visualized
item.description: Here's a chart that shows how the increase of average hourly wages compares to the increases in goods and services such as healthcare, tuition and housing.

item.title: How The Virus Has Changed The Way We Use The Internet, Charted
item.description: With many stuck at home during the pandemic, Americans have been spending more of their lives online. This is how our habits have changed.

item.title: The Olympics Timeline Has Been Cruel To Simone Biles
item.description: Her birthdate already kept her from more gold medals — and a delayed Olympics won't help.

item.title: How To Read The Coronavirus Graphs
item.description: "Flatten the curve" works for linear graphs. But we're increasingly seeing exponential growth plotted on logarithmic graphs.

item.title: How The Coronavirus Death Toll Grew Across The US, Visualized
item.description: The first 5,000 deaths came in just over a month's time, and in fewer than five days, the second 5,000 followed. This map shows how quickly the death toll has risen in metro areas across the country.

item.title: Here's When Your State Will Run Out Of Hospital Beds
item.description: New projections paint a grim picture for the country in the coming weeks.

item.title: The Percentage Of American Workers In Each Income Bracket, Visualized
item.description: According to the data, more than half of workers in the US earn less than $50,000 a year.

item.title: Does My County Have an Epidemic? Estimates Show Hidden Transmission
item.description: Even counties that have few reported cases probably already have sustained, undetected outbreaks, a study finds.

item.title: Coronavirus Cases In The United States By County From February To April, Visualized
item.description: A Redditor created an animated data visualization of the spread of coronavirus over the United States from February to April after looking at numbers provided by The New York Times.

item.title: Coronavirus Case Counts Are Meaningless
item.description: "The number of reported COVID-19 cases is not a very useful indicator of anything unless you also know something about how tests are being conducted."

item.title: Cities That Went All In On Social Distancing In 1918 Emerged Stronger For It
item.description: They had lower mortality rates from the influenza pandemic. But their economies also appeared to fare better.

item.title: Location Data Says It All: Staying At Home During Coronavirus Is A Luxury
item.description: "People want to talk about this virus as an equal opportunity pathogen, but it's really not. It's going right to the fissures in our society."

item.title: The Social Distancing Of America
item.description: Smartphone data shows changing habits as coronavirus spreads.

item.title: How Fast The Coronavirus Outbreak Is Growing In Hundreds Of US Communities
item.description: Tracking coronavirus growth rates in metro areas around the nation.
item.kicker: NEW YORK IS JUST THE START

item.title: The Numbers Of Jobless Claims In The US From 1987 To Right Now, Visualized
item.description: 6.6 million Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week, a startling historical high.

item.title: The Countries With The Most Confirmed Coronavirus Cases Per Capita From January To April, Visualized
item.description: Since originating in Wuhan, China, the coronavirus pandemic has affected virtually every country in the world — but some countries have been hit considerably harder than others.

item.title: Where America Didn't Stay Home Even As The Virus Spread, Visualized
item.description: Travel patterns, based on anonymous cellphone data from 15 million people, suggests people living in Florida and the southeast have resisted calls to stay home.

item.title: Charting Where Coronavirus Has Changed US Driving Habits The Most
item.description: It's not just faster drive times. In some cities, commuters have drastically changed their driving patterns.

item.title: A Chart Showing How Long It Took For Coronavirus To Become The Leading Daily Cause Of Death In The US
item.description: Here's how the number of people killed by COVID-19 has changed from March 1 to April 8 and how that compares with the average numbers of the top 15 leading causes of death in the US.

item.title: Nine Charts Showing What Coronavirus Is Doing To The Economy
item.description: Jobless claims are already at record numbers, and it's getting worse.

item.title: The Evolution Of The American Census Questions
item.description: What changes each decade, what stays the same and what do the questions say about American culture and society?

item.title: The Unpredictable Curve Of COVID-19
item.description: The "flatten the curve graphic" and message are mainstream at this point. Now we need to start to grapple with the reality that the actual "curve" of COVID-19 won't be as smooth as last week's infographics may have implied.

item.title: A Helpful Visualization That Shows Whether Or Not We've Succeeded In Stopping Coronavirus
item.description: One of the scariest things about pandemics is the exponential growth of cases. Here's a useful graph that helps us understand whether or not we've made progress in stopping the disease.

item.title: How The Coronavirus Spreads Under Different Simulations Ranging From Lax Restrictions To Extreme Social Distancing And Early Testing
item.description: 3blue1brown's Grant Sanderson looks at a variety of scenarios and demonstrates which are the most effective for stopping the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: The Coronavirus Isn't Just A Blue State Problem
item.description: Detected cases are higher in blue states, but growing faster in red states.
item.kicker: THE VIRUS DOESN'T CARE WHAT YOUR PARTY IS

item.title: A Visualization Of The Potential Spread Of The Coronavirus Connected To A Single Beach During Spring Break
item.description: Tectonix GEO ran an analysis using data from Xmode Social to see the travel paths of anonymized mobile devices that were active at Spring Break at one single Ft. Lauderdale beach. The results are frightening (and not just the potential viral spread — seeing this granular cell phone movement tracking is… troubling).

item.title: Some US Cities Could Have Coronavirus Outbreaks Worse Than Wuhan's
item.description: If the rate of growth in coronavirus cases in the New York metro area continues, it will suffer a more severe outbreak than those experienced in Wuhan, China, or the Lombardy region of Italy.
